video_title: Watch This Before Buying a Laser Cutter & Engraver in 2025
comment_text:
Warning! Do NOT buy a low end open frame uv diode laser.   I bought one and the laser kept lighting the material on fire. Because I had to constantly watch out for fires I damaged my eyesight permanently even with safety glasses on.   

No deal is ever worth your eyesight!!!

Buy an enclosed laser with enough power to cut through the material. Gas assist lasers will prevent fires.  

Again stay away from uv lasers they‚Äôre only really good for engraving on wood not cutting anything.

video_title: Why is xTool so Popular - The P2S Desktop Laser Review
comment_text:
I'm sticking with my Atomstack pre-order for my first CO2 laser. The PS2 has some nice features, but for the lower price, red dot alignment & full Lightburn support is my main reason (the PS2 & S in Lightburn doesn't support camera or auto-focus).

The pull-out fan is handy but probably easy to swap on Hurricane and won't be often. The simple filter on the PS2 was a nice touch but will probably look at adding some strip magnets and fan mesh to the Atomstack for the same effect when it arrives.

video_title: Make This With Your Laser To Leave Your Day Job
comment_text: Great video but your Etsy fees are way low.  Yeah, it's 6.5% transaction fee but also a 3% processing fee.  If the order comes in via their "Offsite Ads" then it's another 12% off the entire order including shipping.  That's 21.5% and I think I'm missing one off the top of my head as I had figured it up in the "worst case scenario" with an order with Offsite Ads at almost 25%.  Since you don't know when those sales happen or have any visibility to how they happen, you have to be prepared for them.

video_title: Why is xTool so Popular - The P2S Desktop Laser Review
comment_text:
Does this "smart align - take an image and get a proper placement on the material" really work?
I have tried so many times to use various cameras with Lightburn (Atomstack x20 pro, including the original Atomstack camera kit) to place content precisely - it's ALWAYS disappointing. 

Not only for the obvious reasons: 
If you use material with different thickness, you need to re-calibrate. 
And it's really hard to mount a camera over a laser in a consistent spot: all constructins I have seen with beams and tripods and "mount to a lid" just didn't have the accuracy required for it to be useful. The camera will always move a tiny bit out of calibration.
Not only that, but even if you really mount it as sturdy as possible and have the same thickness of material all the time, it will just by itself loose calibration within 2-3 runs.
Not only that, even if you use fixed jigs (no camera), the laser itself isn't consistent in positioning, you may get 2-5mm shifts randomly.

So all in all the Lightburn camera alignment feature is just a collosal disappointment.

Is that what you show in the video - randomly positioned material with accurate detection and accurate positioning - REALLY REALLY reality or is that staged B.S.? Does it REALLY get the content onto the material in the right angle, in the right place?
Can there be a proper review of this feature, please?

Thanks!

video_title: The New Craft Room King? - xTool M1 Ultra Review
comment_text: Nice reveiw,    very informative and entertaining.     I have to wonder about this machine as far as laser printing being compatible with paper and vinyl cutting.   Lasering is often a a smoky messy process,  the inside of a laser cutter needs a lot of cleaning.     It might be challenging to keep the sort of clean room environment you want for cloth and paper in the same environment with laser cutting.

video_title: Watch This Before Buying a Laser Cutter & Engraver in 2025
comment_text: Buy a cheap Chinese diode, a Good (like OMTech) Fiber and a decent (80watts or more) CO2. Yeah 3 lasers... and while there's a lot of crossover in capabilities, you don't want to use your CO2 (tube replacement is expensive) or fiber for stuff your diode can do.

video_title: Watch This Before Buying a Laser Cutter & Engraver in 2025
comment_text:
Please stop referring to the Xtool F1 as a fibre laser.  It's an IR & visible light diode galvo machine.  Xtool muddied the water by marketing it as a fibre, then wondered why people were annoyed by the misrepresentation.
The F1 Ultra, however, *is* a fibre laser.
